description: {"blocks":[{"key":"25rpr","text":"As the number of sequenced insect genomes continues to grow, there is a pressing need for rapid and accurate annotation of their regulatory component. SCRMshaw is a computational tool designed to predict cis-regulatory modules (CRMs) in the genomes of various insect species (Kantorovitz 2009; Kazemian 2011; Asma and Halfon 2019; Asma 2024).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":204,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"80q5v","text":"One of the key advantages of SCRMshaw is its accessibility. It requires minimal resources—just a genome sequence and training data from known Drosophila CRMs, which are readily available for download. Even users with modest computational skills can run SCRMshaw on a desktop computer for basic applications, although an HPC cluster is recommended for optimal results. SCRMshaw can be tailored to specific needs. Users can employ a single set of training data to predict CRMs associated with a particular gene expression pattern, or utilize multiple sets to provide a rough regulatory annotation for a newly-sequenced genome.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":142,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"624qa","text":"This protocol provides an update to the protocol in Kazemian and Halfon (2019) and incorporates modifications introduced in Asma and Halfon (2019) and Asma et al. (2024).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"aaeud","text":"Computational considerations:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":29}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1t5md","text":"The SCRMshaw_HD pipeline can analyze an average-sized insect genome using several training sets in a matter of hours; we are able to run all but the largest or most fragmented genomes with our full default set of 48 training sets in under 72 hours. The bulk of the computational time is spent in the SCRMshaw step. To decrease run times, chromosomes and/or training sets can be split out and run as separate instances on additional sets of 25 nodes, if available, as a simple parallelization strategy. Storage space increases with genome size, mostly due to the larger number of kmers that must be stored, and can grow to several TB with larger genomes. However, the majority of this space can be released upon completion of the pipeline by deleting intermediate and temporary files, using “cleanup” scripts we have made available. If sufficient temporary storage space is not available, it is advisable to run the original lightweight SCRMshaw (Kazemian and Halfon, 2019) rather than SCRMshaw_HD, which will keep storage requirements below 100GB for most genomes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b9m77","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"60r9i","text":"Running Orthologer using Singularity:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":37},{"style":"italic","offset":8,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6q7ct","text":"Orthologer is currently distributed as a Docker container. Many HPC environments do not allow deployment of Docker files, but can run Singularity (Aptainer) images. To run Orthologer using Singularity, you must first create a Singularity image from the Orthologer Docker image. You may need to do this on a local machine and then transfer the Singularity image to your HPC cluster. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":11},{"style":"italic","offset":172,"length":10},{"style":"italic","offset":253,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bk5bj","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ag6aq","text":"From the Ortholger GitLab site (https://gitlab.com/ezlab/orthologer_container):","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":79}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":32,"length":45}],"data":{}},{"key":"fjoq9","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4shp6","text":"## {"blocks":[{"key":"5ih1q","text":"Preflight validates the formats of these files and produces a comprehensive log file that highlights any issues along with basic information such as the number of chromosomes/scaffolds and their sizes, data types present in the annotation (e.g., ‘gene’, ‘exon’, ‘ncRNA’, etc.), and average intergenic distances. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"et6aa","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3og7h","text":"Preflight also provides a sample output of the SCRMshaw-generated ‘gene’ and ‘exon’ files. This feature allows users to identify any discrepancies or errors stemming from the input files and to reformat these files as needed before running SCRMshaw. Be sure to check the following:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ld96","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bma2o","text":"In the first section, no GFF3 errors are reported","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d9maq","text":"Gene and Exon data appear in the following sections","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e5ag3","text":"The ‘FASTA’ section reports “all sequences have proper characters”","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"djbn9","text":"The following section reports that “All seqids in GFF are also in FASTA”","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"env3b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7ia8s","text":"If any of these conditions is not met, correct the input files before moving on to run SCRMshaw, or SCRMshaw will fail.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a7d1p","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2pifv","text":"Preflight will also indicate whether there are sequence scaffolds that do not contain any annotated genes (reported as “seqids not in the GFF file.”) Any such sequence scaffolds should be removed before passing the genome sequence to the main SCRMshaw program. Perform this using the “extract_unannotatedScaffolds.py” script (from ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"13oej","text":"https://github.com/HalfonLab/UtilityPrograms) that takes the preflight output file and FASTA sequence file as input and generates a fasta file, “mappedOnly_GCF_xxxxx.fna”, that contains only the desired sequences.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":45}],"data":{}},{"key":"2qbhq","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bs1qb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8j76n","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"45aag","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"ED6413DF180311EF80020A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://github.com/HalfonLab/UtilityPrograms)"}},"1":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"“extracting unannotated scaffolds”","description":"","guid":"9A42E27A21B911EF83720A58A9FEAC02","name":"python ../Scripts/extract_unannotatedScaffolds.py -po preflight_output_file.txt -fasta GCF_xxxxxxxxx.fna","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"f4v66","text":"The extract_unannoatatedScaffolds.py script requires biopython","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{},"guid":"F5C9BD7C72FE49F6838A0B2ED7477471"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"13u7k","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bmgeu","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"dj909","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2i619","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"enug5","text":"Download the current version of TRF for your computer architecture from ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4s9gg","text":"https://tandem.bu.edu/trf/home (e.g., trf409.linux64).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":30}],"data":{}},{"key":"d2c0m","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1tm94","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5fqsj","text":"Tandem repeats, as the name indicates, consist of a repeated pattern of one or more nucleotides that occur directly after each other. An example would be ACACACACAC, where the dinucleotide “AC” is repeated five times. The occurrence of a long tandem repeat in the training dataset or the region to be scored significantly skews the distribution of k-mer counts toward the repeated pattern, which would result in assignment of a “false” high score to regions with one or more occurrences of the repeated pattern. To avoid this potential issue, tandem repeats in both the training datasets and the genome to be searched are masked prior to running SCRMshaw using Tandem Repeat Finder (Benson, 1999). To mask tandem repeats:","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{},"guid":"E974FF2859D146C59D884F61CDAAC1B7"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"E41FC00A180411EF80020A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://tandem.bu.edu/trf/home"}},"2":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"“example download command for TRF”","description":"","guid":"9A42E28F21B911EF83720A58A9FEAC02","name":"curl -JLO ../Scripts/ https://github.com/Benson-Genomics-Lab/TRF/releases/download/v4.09.1/trf409.linux64","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

We are currently investigating whether to adjust the TRF parameters on a per-genome basis. However, we have found these parameters to be generally effective for a wide range of genomes.","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4efmo","text":"TRF substitutes the repeated nucleotides with “N” characters that can be fed directly into SCRMshaw. If using a different tool for masking repeats, be sure that the repeated nucleotides are replaced by the same number of “N” characters.","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8conc","text":" If you have constructed custom training sets, make sure to also run TRF on the positive and negative training sequences, as described in Kazemian and Halfon (2019).","type":"unordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{},"guid":"BF48A3AF94574AEE9033C279DA8B1CF3"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6kue6","text":"SCRMshaw requires the following files and directories:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5lk91","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5seub","text":"A genome file (e.g., “genome.fa”), a multi-FASTA file including all of the genomic sequences needing to be scored. This is typically a downloaded genome file that has been masked for tandem repeats, and is passed to the program using the “--genome\" option.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4vlmv","text":"One or more dataset directories each containing two files, “crms.fasta” and “neg.fasta.” These files are respectively the positive and negative training sequences, both in FASTA file format. We highly recommend tandem repeat masking of genome.fa, crms.fasta, and neg.fasta.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aj5h6","text":"A text file containing a list of the dataset directories (e.g., “trainingSet.lst”; see below step 17). This is specified using the “--traindirlst” option.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4lfr0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"f1j74","text":"Run SCRMshaw by providing the full paths to the genome file, gene annotation file, and training set list after the --genome, --gff, and --traindirlst flags, respectively (e.g. GenomeFiles/SpeciesX.gff), and providing appropriate values for --lb and --outdir (see Note).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6n452","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"52p3u","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"“Running SCRMshaw”","description":"","guid":"9A42E33321B911EF83720A58A9FEAC02","name":"perl SCRMshaw_HD/code/scrm.pl --thitw 5000 --gff GenomeFiles/SpeciesX.gff --genomeGenomeFiles/mappedOnly_GCF_xxxxx.fna.2.7.7.80.10.50.500.mask --traindirlst trainingSet.lst --imm --\n","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6ovim","text":"We recommend that the base directory for --outdir be set to ~/project1/HD_output for consistency with the examples in this protocol.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ffu83","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8rlaf","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"alp5r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bm50s","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e5n51","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"73p2p","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"afo3p","text":"SCRMshaw_HD requires running 25 concurrent instances with the “window start” incremented by 10 for each instance. ","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3ejiq","text":"For optimal efficiency, we recommend performing this computation on a computing cluster. Execute each of the 25 instances independently, enabling straightforward parallelization. ","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":85,"offset":122}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7lfjg","text":"An illustrative script utilizing the Slurm manager is available for download as \"Slurm_script_SCRMshawHD.sh\" from GitHub (https://github.com/HalfonLab/UtilityPrograms/blob/master/Slurm_script_SCRMshawHD.sh); this script sets appropriate values for the $myNUM and $SLURM_TASK_DIR variables in the code example above. ","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"c9j3n","text":"If a different workflow manager, other than Slurm, is employed, ensure the correct syntax for the respective scheduler and appropriate values for the --lb and --outdir parameters. File names also need to be generated correctly to prevent any disruptions to downstream scripts.","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ftqdu","text":"This process is analogous to merely adjusting the default shift size parameter from 250 bp to 10 bp and adhering to the fundamental SCRMshaw protocol (as described in Kazemian and Halfon, 2019), allowing for execution on a single processor. However, the latter approach would substantially increase the execution time, especially for a large genome. ","type":"unordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"586CA697180811EF80020A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://github.com/HalfonLab/UtilityPrograms/blob/master/Slurm_script_SCRMshawHD.sh);"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"}},"guid":"3419C91F54A84807AA4393113B33BD72"}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1bd3j","text":"To execute traditional SCRMshaw (not the \"HD\" version), set the --lb option to 0, and specify an appropriate file name for \"--outdir\". If using Slurm, remove the sbatch --array option (e.g. \"#SBATCH --array=1-25\") from the Slurm script.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{},"guid":"F6FDE7961A1445B4938D356AE17ED15B"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3mj8g","text":"The output of SCRMshaw for the 25 offset instances will be saved in subdirectories, such as 'task_offset_0_1', 'task_offset_10_2', 'task_offset_20_3', and so on up to 'task_offset_240_25', as specified by the '--outdir' parameter in the Slurm script. These directories will be created automatically if they don't already exist. If Slurm is not utilized, it is crucial to ensure that the output directory and file names adhere to the specified format (e.g., 'task_offset_0_1' to 'task_offset_240_25') to prevent any downstream disruptions. \n","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"d6jc6","text":"The SCRMshaw command line options include:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8dma7","text":"Use the name of scoring method(s) for prediction (“--imm” for IMM, “--hexmcd” for HexMCD, and “--pac” for PAC): required. Select any individual or combination of methods to run (e.g. “--imm --pac” to run IMM and PAC). For details about the individual scoring methods see (Kantorovitz et al. 2009, Kazemian et al. 2011).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8avs7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8v5gc","text":"The gene annotation file of the genomic regions to be scored in GFF3 format (e.g., “--gff SpeciesX.gff”): optional but strongly recommended. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fn840","text":"Alternatively, separate “gene” and “exon” files can be used. It is also possible to use SCRMshaw without providing any annotation, but this will not allow for exclusion of coding sequences or calculation of “local rank” (see below).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6jhk1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fl7nh","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bu064","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"c6s85","text":" Individual “gene” and “exon” files can be used in lieu of an annotation GFF3 file; one or both files can be provided.","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"c4813","text":"These should be tab-delimited lists of gene or exon coordinates, respectively, in the form chromosome (or scaffold), start coordinate, end coordinate, strand (+ or -), gene ID/exon ID (e.g., gene_name:1). ","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"a2u7v","text":"In the absence of an annotation GFF3 file, running SCRMshaw without a “gene” file will preclude calculation of local rank and provision of results indicating closest flanking genes. ","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"e3sua","text":"Omitting an “exon” file will prevent masking of exons and allow coding regions to be scored as potential CRMs, which is strongly discouraged. ","type":"unordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{},"guid":"97B2648DE4AD4985BA69704C4DD00E30"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8q9co","text":"The number of top scoring regions to be reported as CRM predictions (--thitw N): optional, default = 2000.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bkbu7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cj1gr","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"36vqv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6j6j5","text":"Adjust the reported number of predictions depending on expectations of how many CRMs might be recovered, for instance based on how functionally broad or specific the training CRMs are.","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"af835","text":"At the moment, we do not have a systematic way of learning this parameter from the input training sets. We recommend using a generous value, and then if desired working with a smaller subset of results obtained using the “Generate_top_N_SCRMhits” script that can be downloaded from ","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":83,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bc9fi","text":"https://github.com/HalfonLab/UtilityPrograms/blob/master/Generate_top_N_SCRMhits.pl","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"5CD4C850180A11EF80020A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://github.com/HalfonLab/UtilityPrograms/blob/master/Generate_top_N_SCRMhits.pl"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"}},"guid":"71CF2A63F6FC4976923F758C50C66467"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"371bd","text":"The offset parameter --lb: optional, default = 0. The --lb tells the algorithm to ignore the base pairs at the beginning of a chromosome/scaffold before this point, i.e., to start creating the analysis windows from this point in the genome. The Slurm script described above sets --lb from 0 to 240 with a step size of 10 (i.e 10, 20, 30,..., 240) for the 25 instances being run for each training set.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c3qfm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1rvl9","text":"Which steps of the SCRMshaw pipeline to run (--step 123): optional, default = 123. Step 1 processes the genome and genome annotation, step 2 processes the training data, and step 3 scores the genome.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6t3mc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6q3tq","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8hqd0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ab3eg","text":"For a given genome, we recommend first running SCRMshaw with a limited number of training datasets and the “--step” option set to “--step 123.” ","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3l9iu","text":"This will process the genome and annotation, and ensure that create all of the proper subdirectories. ","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ca7g6","text":"Parallel instances of SCRMshaw can then be run with additional training sets and “--step 23.” To run an additional scoring method for a previously run training set (e.g., if only “--imm” was run initially and you now want to add “--hexmcd”), only “--step 3” is necessary.","type":"unordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{},"guid":"0ECAC1213946474F937A1E12D6B1C5CE"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1l1bs","text":"Detailed information on how to run SCRMshaw from the command line and additional available options can be obtained by the following command: “perl SCRMshaw_HD/code/scrm.pl” or from the README document accompanying the SCRMshaw distribution. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7kivi","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"45g0s","text":"An example benchmark data set along with how to run and interpret its results is provided in the example directory within the software package.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4gfe6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8174v","text":"The post-processing steps merge the data from the 25 SCRMshaw instances and select the top-scoring regions as CRM predictions. Use the path to the GFF annotation file for SCRMshaw and enter as a command line argument:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d7mcp","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6gaan","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"“post-processing”","description":"","guid":"9A42E34821B911EF83720A58A9FEAC02","name":"./Scripts/post_processing_complete.sh GenomeFiles/SpeciesX.gff","os_name":"","os_version":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8g0i","text":"log_flankingMoreThanOneGenesFromAllSets.txt: a log file documenting cases of SCRMshaw predictions where there is more than a single flanking gene either up- or steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"cggso","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"hh6d","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"a6jm4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f3cc9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bqjij","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d54o2","text":"Generate a gene ID ⇔ protein ID mapping file","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"303u7","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9a4gf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4ndtr","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8jkqp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8mgfe","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6ve3e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ahqsc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":16,"offset":50,"style":"italic"}],"key":"60iju","text":"The previous steps map SpeciesX proteins to their D. melanogaster orthologs, but our SCRMshaw predictions have associated gene IDs and not protein IDs. We therefore need an intermediate mapping file to associate protein IDs and gene IDs. This mapping file can be generated based on information in the SpeciesXannotation GFF file. However, there is considerable variation in how the necessary information is presented in GFFs compiled by different research groups. Therefore, you may need to customize your approach depending on the exact nature of the annotations. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1dhrp","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1mahl","text":"The below line of code will work when the relevant gene ID and protein ID are both listed for a CDS annotation line, with the correct gene ID given as “gene”.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{},"guid":"707EE6E6F200466888899885AFA89651"}},"1":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"“Sample code for generating a gene⇔protein mapping file  (Using Perl)”","description":"","guid":"9A42E49021B911EF83720A58A9FEAC02","name":"perl -F'\\t' -ane 'next if $_ =~ /#/; if ($F[2] =~ /CDS/){$F[8] =~ /gene=(.*?);.*protein_id=(.*)/; print \"$1\\t$2\\n\";}' speciesX.gff | sort -u \u003e speciesX_A.map","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"2":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"“Sample code for generating a gene⇔protein mapping file  (Using sed)”","description":"","guid":"9A42E4B321B911EF83720A58A9FEAC02","name":"sed -n '/#/d; /CDS/ {s/.*gene=\\([^;]*\\);.*protein_id=\\([^;]*\\).*/\\1\\t\\2/; p; }' speciesX.gff | sort -u \u003e speciesX_A.map","os_name":"","os_version":""}},"3":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3cm6n","text":"Because there are often multiple CDS lines for a single gene, we piped the above command through “sort -u” to remove any duplicate lines. We recommend this step of removing duplicate lines, either at this step or following final editing of the mapping file, before running the “OM_mappingFlyOrthologsToSCRMshawPredictions.py” script.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{},"guid":"A1593E0ED38840F1B4AFB0F31484C510"}}}}
